name: cygnus-cygnus
definition: A large white swan of Europe and Asia, having a loud whooping call.
description:
The whooper swan is a big migratory bird and is considered the most elegant of the swan family.

They have pure white feathers. It has a long thin neck, which it usually holds erect. Their webbed feet and their legs are black.

Half the beak at the base is orangey-yellow and the tip is black.

The markings on the beak differ between individuals and they can be recognized by means of the pattern.

Juveniles are usually white but some are gray.

Whooper swan is considered to be amongst the heaviest flying birds.

The verified record mass was 15.5 kilograms for a wintering male from Denmark.

Like their close relatives, whooper swans are vocal birds with a call similar to the trumpeter swan.

Whooper swans require large areas of water to live in, especially when they are still growing.

This is because their body weight cannot be supported by their legs for extended periods of time.

Their preferred breeding habitat is wetland, but semi-domesticated birds will build a nest anywhere close to water.

They favor habitats with emergent vegetation, and this may offer additional protection for their nests and the newborn cygnets.

A whooper swan feeds in shallow water and eats aquatic plants and roots.

The young eat small insects and a variety of invertebrates to satisfy their high protein needs for growth and development.

Whooper swans will often feed on fields, eating crops like leftover potatoes and grain, before heading to roost on open water.

Whooper swans breed in subarctic Eurasia.

They pair for life, and their cygnets stay with them all winter; they are sometimes joined by offspring from previous years.

Both the male and female help build the nest, and the male will stand guard over the nest while the female incubates.

The female will usually lay 4 to 7 eggs.

The cygnets hatch after about 36 days and have a grey or brown plumage.

The cygnets can fly at an age of 120 to 150 days.

The whooper swan spends much of its time swimming, straining the water for food, or eating plants that grow on the bottom.

Whooper swans have a deep honking call and, despite their size, are powerful fliers.

They can migrate hundreds or even thousands of miles to their wintering sites in southern Europe and eastern Asia.

New born cygnets are mainly lost to herons, turtles, pike and large perch.

Adults do not have many predators due to their habitat condition.

Whooper swans are much admired in Europe.

The whooper swan is the national bird of Finland and is featured on the Finnish 1 euro coin.

related.definition: A wild duck found almost worldwide, the male of which has a green head and neck. Most domestic ducks descend from the mallard.
A goose of North America and Siberia that has two color forms, one with white plumage and black wingtips and the other with bluish-gray plumage and a white head.
The common goldeneye  is a medium-sized sea duck of the genus Bucephala, the goldeneyes.
